qas.question: after about what year did railroads bring hunters to the great plains?
what animal did hunters kill off for their hides?
what farmers rushed in to settle the land with the help of the railroads?
what did the railroads offer the farmers that rushed in to settle the area?
In what year were the homestead laws passed?
How many towns existed in Kansas in 1950?
How many free farms were doled out overall?
How many cities existed in Kansas as of 2000?
How many bison were killed for their hides?

context: After <a0_0><b4_0>1870<b4_0/><a0_0/>, the new railroads across the Plains brought hunters who killed off almost all the <a1_0>bison<a1_0/> for their hides. The railroads offered attractive <a3_0>packages of land and transportation<a3_0/> to <a2_0>European farmers<a2_0/>, who rushed to settle the land. They (and Americans as well) also took advantage of the homestead laws to obtain free farms. Land speculators and local boosters identified many potential towns, and those reached by the railroad had a chance, while the others became ghost towns. In Kansas, for example, nearly <b6_0><b8_0>5000<b8_0/><b6_0/> towns were mapped out, but by 1970 only <b5_0><b7_0>617<b7_0/><b5_0/> were actually operating. In the mid-20th century, closeness to an interstate exchange determined whether a town would flourish or struggle for business.
